bug.short_desc: JDT's implementation of JSR-199 reports wrong errors with classes generated by Annotation Processing Tool

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 238276 Patch + Maven project
When using Eclipse compiler through JSR-199 interface (e.g. in IntelliJ IDEA), classes generated with Annotation Processing Tool are reported as missing during main classes compilation.
As example, I provide a small Maven project in attachment. Compiling it with Maven (using Eclipse compiler) works fine, but not with IntelliJ CE.
Having looked carefully at the code, it appears that batch compiler and JSR-199 do not report errors in the same way. I also provide a patch that fixes it. Feel free to incorporate it in ECJ sour code.
Thanks,
Best regards,
Gauthier

Thank you ! Guathier, you need to sign up the eclipse contributor agreement http://www.eclipse.org/legal/CLA.php and certify here to these stipulations: http://www.eclipse.org/legal/CoO.php
Jay, please take it forward.

See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=415308#c32 for example. If you have done in correctly, against your name you should see a green check mark in buzgilla's "Reported by" field instead of the - I see now.

Done, there's now a green 'v' near my name.
Regards,
Gauthier

(In reply to Gauthier JACQUES from comment #3) > Done, there's now a green 'v' near my name.
Thanks, you still need to add a statement here that your contribution compiles with the agreement a la https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=415308#c32.

SignOff Comment:
My contribution complies with http://www.eclipse.org/legal/CoO.php

The eclipse developers are not supposed to use IntelliJ. So, I don't know how they use the JavaCompiler interfaces. So it's difficult for me to imagine why reporting problems through ProblemFactory/DiagnosticListener is a problem, esp. only in the case files created by annotation processing? Can you please add some details of your investigation? TIA!
I believe this is not Java 8 specific. So, we can target Luna M5 for this and later pull into the Java 8 branch.

I find this note in the IProblemFactory, may be this explains it:
* Factory used from inside the compiler to build the actual problems * which are handed back in the compilation result. * * This allows sharing the internal problem representation with the environment.
Gauthier, it would still be good if you can share your analysis.

(In reply to Jayaprakash Arthanareeswaran from comment #6) > The eclipse developers are not supposed to use IntelliJ. So, I don't know > how they use the JavaCompiler interfaces. So it's difficult for me to > imagine why reporting problems through ProblemFactory/DiagnosticListener is > a problem, esp. only in the case files created by annotation processing? Can > you please add some details of your investigation? TIA!
Hi Gauthier, I would appreciate some details when you have some time.

Hi, sorry for the delay, I've been very busy lately.
I'll try to remember : we patched this months ago (in ECJ 4.2.x first then ECJ 4.3.x) and have been using the patched compiler in our software factories since then.
I added logging in the compiler and launched it on the same code through Maven (batch compiler) and IntelliJ (JSR-199 interface). This showed me that "missing generated classes" problems are actually created by the ProblemFactory in both the batch and jsr199 compiler.
Now the difference : with the batch compiler these problems are no longer present in "compilationResult.getAllProblems()" and the compilation succeed. With JSR-199, the overriden ProblemFactory in EclipseCompilerImpl reports these errors as they are created to the DiagnosticListener and the compilation fails, even though "compilationResult.getAllProblems()" does not report any error (JSR-199 API compilation success or failure is based on error reported to DiagnosticListener).
What I did to fix it : I removed the overriden problem factory and kept the default one, and created a BatchRequestor object, that retrieves errors from "compilationResult.getAllProblems()" and feed them, if any, in the DiagnosticListener at the end of the compilation.
Like this, errors reported to the DiagnosticListener of the JSR-199 API are exactly the same as the one reported by the batch compiler.
Hope this help. Please note that some of the changes in the patch may be cosmetic (method or inner class extraction for more readable code).
Best regards,
Gauthier

(In reply to Gauthier JACQUES from comment #10) > Hope this help. Please note that some of the changes in the patch may be > cosmetic (method or inner class extraction for more readable code).
It certainly does and thanks! I will look to get this in for M5.

I have done one round of review and things mostly look good. Still have to run some tests, as few questions still remain:
1. Why does EclipseDiagnostic leave out the MANDATORY_WARNING, which was considered earlier in the getKind() ? 2. Is there still need for the Main#getBatchRequestor() and the anonymous sub type of ICompilerRequestor? In any case, we can avoid code duplication if we name this sub type and let the new EclipseBatchRequestor extend it.
Continuing to look at the patch.

Created attachment 239124 Patch with copyright
I have done bit of formatting (all whitespace changes) and added copyright header to the new files. I also figured that changes to the DefaultProblemFactory in your patch was purely cosmetic and removed them. Please correct me if I am wrong.

(In reply to Jayaprakash Arthanareeswaran from comment #12) > 1. Why does EclipseDiagnostic leave out the MANDATORY_WARNING, which was > considered earlier in the getKind() ? > 2. Is there still need for the Main#getBatchRequestor() and the anonymous > sub type of ICompilerRequestor? In any case, we can avoid code duplication > if we name this sub type and let the new EclipseBatchRequestor extend it. > > Continuing to look at the patch.
These all are the questions I have.
Gauthier, for legal reasons, I can't make code changes to your patch. Do you have some time to look at these questions and incorporates the suggestions as applicable? Thanks!
Looks like this may not make it to M5.

Hi Jay, I don't forget you, I'll have a look at the question you asked as soon as I can.
Regards,
Gauthier
Moving out of M6.

We are almost at the end of M7, the last milestones before release cycles begin.
Gauthier, do you have some time at your hand to respond to my questions? The questions/suggestions I posted in comment #12 should be straight forward ones to incorporate. If you are busy with your work, I can understand, in which case, I suggest we revisit for 4.5.

(In reply to Jayaprakash Arthanareeswaran from comment #18) > We are almost at the end of M7, the last milestones before release cycles > begin. > > Gauthier, do you have some time at your hand to respond to my questions? The > questions/suggestions I posted in comment #12 should be straight forward > ones to incorporate. If you are busy with your work, I can understand, in > which case, I suggest we revisit for 4.5.
Hi Jay,
I'll try to have a look at it this week, but not before Thursday. Is this OK for you ?
Regards,
Gauthier

(In reply to Gauthier JACQUES from comment #19) > Hi Jay, > > I'll try to have a look at it this week, but not before Thursday. Is this OK > for you ?
Sure, that would be okay.
Too late for Luna now.

Created attachment 245784 New patch that fixes the issue.
Hi Jay,
I've just upgraded our local copy of ECJ to 4.4 so we can benefit of Java 8 features in IntelliJ, and I took the time to look at your questions.
So :
- Concerning getKind() and the value MANDATORY_WARNING : it is never returned by the original implementation because the condition
((severity & ProblemSeverities.Warning) != 0)
is always false : since ProblemSeverities.Warning is 0. A 'bitwise and' with it will always return 0.
- Concerning the anonymous ICompilerRequestor class in Main, yes we can extract it to a named class and extend it for the EclipseCompilerImpl usage. We just have to keep the method reportProblems() in the super class, even though there is no need for any implementation there, but is required in the sub-class to perform its extra job.
I created a patch that do that, and should work on ECJ 4.4 sources.
Sorry for the long delay,
Best regards,
Gauthier
Thanks Gauthier. Will look at this during M2.

Hello Gauthier,
I have trouble pushing your code. Can you check if you have gerrit account? Thanks!
----------- Gauthier JACQUES <gauthier.jacques@gmail.com>
error: The author does not have a Gerrit account. All authors must either be a commiter on the project, or have a current CLA on file. Please see http://wiki.eclipse.org/CLA ------------------

Hi Jay,
Since I don't know what Gerrit is, I probably don't have an account. Can you indicate may how I can create one ?
Thanks,
GAuthier

In fact I can login here : https://git.eclipse.org/ with my Eclipse account, isn't this enough ?
Regards,
Gauthier

(In reply to Gauthier JACQUES from comment #26) > In fact I can login here : https://git.eclipse.org/ with my Eclipse account, > isn't this enough ?
It usually is. But I was trying to push it through Gerrit code review system - Gerrit also allows me to create build and run tests the way it is done in official eclipse builds. Anyway, I will push the fix the usual way. That should work.

Thanks Gauthier for your efforts. Fix along with a new test has been released in master via:
http://git.eclipse.org/c/jdt/eclipse.jdt.core.git/commit/?id=65f5152e309a08bb91b2b35f96e93b2fa93bae4f
Verified for Mars 4.5M2 by code inspection.

attachment.desc: New patch that fixes the issue.
